speaker: Frasier
text: Morning, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey Frasier, your brother called.  He said he'll be over at about seven o' clock tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thanks.  So, you seem awfully calm today.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, why shouldn't I be?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, during ratings week you're usually rather anxious.

speaker: Roz
text: [_anxious_] Oh my God!  That starts today?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I never should have mentioned it.

speaker: Roz
text: Ten seconds. [_starts quickly searching through her bag_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Roz, you do this every year, you convince yourself we'll have a disastrous week with no good callers, but our listeners always come through in the end, don't they?

speaker: Roz
text: [_quickly_] You're on!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right. [_into microphone_] Hello Seattle, this is Dr. Frasier Crane.  You know, I was reminded this morning of a jaunty aphorism which is credited to the great thinker Spinoza...

speaker: Roz
text: Oh God! [_takes first call_] Frasier Crane Show, what's your problem?

speaker: Mary
text: [_v.o._] Hi, I'm kind of... indecisive.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I'm not! [_takes next call_] Frasier Crane Show, what's your problem?

speaker: Roger
text: [_v.o._] I'm thinking of changing careers, I feel kinda trapped.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, it's not a very exciting problem, but I'll see if I can get you on.  Hold, please. [_takes next call_] Frasier Crane Show, what's your problem?

speaker: Bill
text: [_v.o._] It's sort of embarrassing.

speaker: Roz
text: Amen!

speaker: Bill
text: I was a bed-wetter as a child and I think the problem's coming back.

speaker: Roz
text: Great.  Hold, please. [_goes back to Roger_] Hey, Career Change, I've got a bed-wetter holding.  When you say "trapped," is it possible you feel you are a woman trapped inside a man's body?

speaker: Roger
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Roz
text: I don't think I can get you on today, then.

speaker: Roger
text: Gee, I really wanted to talk to him... I guess that could be part of it.

speaker: Roz
text: Good answer.  Hold, please. [_to Bill_] Hey Bed-Wetter, I've got a transsexual in crisis, you gotta beat that.  Have you ever wet a bed with anyone else in it?  A hooker, a stripper, or maybe your best friend's wife?

speaker: Bill
text: No.

speaker: Roz
text: Do you want to talk to the doc or not?

speaker: Bill
text: OK.  Er, I guess the third one.

speaker: Roz
text: Hold, please. [_to Roger_] Hey Transsexual.

speaker: Roger
text: Is that me?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  Have you ever run for political office, or considered running for political office?

speaker: Roger
text: What, you mean like congressman or something?

speaker: Roz
text: [_takes that as an answer_] Perfect!

speaker: Frasier
text: ...don't get me started on rationalistic pantheism or I'll go the whole three hours!  Well, I think it's time we went to the phones.  Roz, whom do we have?

speaker: Roz
text: On line one we have a bed-wetting adulterer, unless you'd rather speak to Roger on line two, who's a transsexual running for Congress.

speaker: Frasier
text: Go on then Roger, I'm listening. **IN CASE YOU'RE INTERESTED, IT'S A BROWN ERMINE** _Scene Two - Apartment Daphne, wearing a brown ermine jacket, and Martin enter Frasier's apartment.  Daphne gossips as Martin goes to hang up her coat and Frasier enters with a tea tray._

speaker: Daphne
text: Would you just explain to me why you chickened out like that?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, she's younger than I am!  She probably dates doctors and lawyers, she wouldn't be interested in me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Who wouldn't be interested?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez.

speaker: Daphne
text: A certain someone had the chance to ask a certain someone else from the building on a date.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, that would be Mrs. Crowley.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez!

speaker: Daphne
text: And bailed out again!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, Daphne, don't be too hard on him.  The Crane men haven't had a great deal of success in the romance department lately.  We're all a bit gun-shy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Ah yes, gun-shy, sensitive, picky; you're all full of excuses. [_phone rings_] You know, sometimes I wonder if I'll ever get any of you married off and out of this house.  _Martin and Frasier look at each other in confusion.  Daphne answers the phone._

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello?  Why, Mrs. Crowley, we were just talking about you! Yes he's here, hold on. _She passes the phone to Martin, who glares at Frasier and Daphne, making them stop staring at him.  She brings some tea to Frasier._

speaker: Martin
text: Hi.  Really?  No, I'm not busy, dinner sounds like fun.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_to Frasier_] A certain someone is inviting a certain someone else to dinner.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic_] Yes, where would the world be without you Brits and your knack for code-cracking?

speaker: Martin
text: [_still on phone_] Oh yeah, yeah, sure I'd love to.  Thanks. And thanks for asking me.  Bye. [_puts phone down_] She's invited me to her place tomorrow night.  I guess my little hard-to-get plan really paid off.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, you should really write a book; "How To Get A Date In Two Easy Years."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hello Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.  Hey Dad, hey Daphne.

speaker: Martin
text: What you got there?

speaker: Niles
text: [_holds up his papers_] Oh, just some patient files.  Frasier's helping me with my couples' group tomorrow night.

speaker: Daphne
text: You'r father's starting his own couples' group tomorrow night.

speaker: Niles
text: Ha! [_realizes_] Oh, Mrs. Crowley?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, _geez!_ [_goes to his room_]

speaker: Frasier
text: It's ironic, isn't it?  Dad's doing better in that department than either of us.

speaker: Niles
text: Not true, not true, that's really what I wanted to tell you. Maris and I are back on the expressway to love!  Well, if not the expressway, then at least the on-ramp.  And I owe it all to the best psychiatrist I have ever known...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh that's very flattering, Niles...

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Bernard Schenkman, our new marriage counselor.  And he is nothing short of a wizard.  And Maris is as thrilled with him as I am.  It's as if he's discovered the magic elixir to repair the shattered fragments of her psyche.  I-I don't know exactly what to call it.

speaker: Frasier
text: The words "Krazy Glue" leap to mind.

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Schenkman's helped me enormously too.  He immediately pinpointed my primary failing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Which is?

speaker: Niles
text: Well... I'm too predictable.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know whether I'd count that as a failing, exactly.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I do, and more importantly, so does Maris.  But I'm going to do something about it.  In half an hour I'm going to show Maris spontaneity beyond her wildest dreams.

speaker: Frasier
text: In half an hour?  I thought we were going to prepare for your workshop!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, you'll have to look over the files yourself.  You see, every Friday evening Maris spends an hour meditating in her spirituality gardens.  Invariably she comes inside randy as a stoat.  Well tonight, she's going to find me, waiting in her bed, as randy as a...nother stoat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gee Niles, I wonder if that's a good idea...

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I know you mean well, and I love you and respect you, so please don't take offense when I point out that, with your track record in relationships, you're about the last person who should be giving advice.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fair enough!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh and do look over the files!  Those couples really need our help. _Niles leaves and we are left with Frasier who begins filing through the notes.  FADE TO:  Scene Two - Mansion Meanwhile, in the bedroom of Maris's mansion an adventure is about to unravel.  The shower in the adjoining room can be heard as Niles rushes in and takes back the bed sheets.  He puts a rose on Maris's pillow and dims the lights.  Niles exits as the shower is turned off.  The showerer comes into the room in pajamas.  It isn't Maris, but Dr. Schenkman.  He slaps some aftershave on before looking at his stomach in the mirror.  He tries to hold it and fails.  Schenkman then sees the rose on the pillow and thinks Maris has dropped it off.  He blows a kiss to the opposite door.  Then he fetches a bottle of champagne in an ice bucket which he nestles by the bed before exiting again.  Niles enters the room again, now dressed in his pajamas.  He notices the bottle of champagne._

speaker: Niles
text: [_saucily_] Hello, Maris! _Niles exits the room again, with a naughty chuckle.  Schenkman re-enters with two glasses.  He kisses the air and fills the first glass, then fills the second and toasts the other door with it. He then exits to the shower room.  Niles enters again.  He puts a CD into a small stereo on the bedside table.  Smoochy classical music sounds and Niles begins swaying. Yet he remembers something else and exits.  Schenkman enters again and notices the music.  He loosens his dressing gown and does a few dance shuffles.  Then he sprays perfume all over the bed, including underneath the covers.  He sprays some on himself before going back to the bathroom.  Niles enters with some rose petals which he excitedly throws over the bed.  Then he hears someone coming out of the bathroom.  He jumps into bed and turns the light out.  Schenkman enters the room and notices "she" is in bed.  He turns out the bathroom light, pitching the room into total blackness.  Schenkman climbs into bed.  The two lovers reach for their ideal mate..._

speaker: Both
text: Maris? [_noticing_] AHHH!  _Niles switches the lights on.  They sit up and scream at each other.  END OF ACT ONE (Time: 8:17)  ACT TWO  Scene One The scene resumes in Maris's bedroom._

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Schenkman!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Schenkman, what the hell's going on?!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Well, it's not what it looks like... what am I saying?

speaker: Niles
text: For God's sake!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Bear with me, I'm sorry.  I'm, I'm feeling a little stressed.

speaker: Niles
text: [_shouting_] You're feeling stressed?!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Put yourself in my place.

speaker: Niles
text: I very nearly did!  I'm stunned!  How... how long has this been going on?

speaker: Schenkman
text: Two weeks.  Maris and I were waiting to tell you when I felt that you were ready.

speaker: Niles
text: That's despicable!  It's unethical, it's... [_notices his clothes_] are those my pajamas?

speaker: Schenkman
text: Could be.  They bind a little in the crotch.  Listen, whatever anger you're feeling can't _begin_ to approach my guilt.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't bet on it!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Ah good, that's good, vent that rage.  You have every right to.

speaker: Niles
text: You're sleeping with my wife and you're giving me permission to be angry?!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Furious.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah-ah.

speaker: Schenkman
text: Livid.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Yes, you're dealing with it very well, by the way.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh!

speaker: Schenkman
text: [_holds up champagne glass_] I don't suppose you'd care-

speaker: Niles
text: No!  Do you realize you could lose your license for having an affair with a patient?

speaker: Schenkman
text: Yes, and I deserve to.  But it was a risk worth taking, because of love. [_lies on the couch, while Niles buries his face in his hand_] Ah... oh!  I love her, Niles.  I've never known a woman so warm... so nurturing... so unselfish...

speaker: Niles
text: Is it possible this is all a case of mistaken identity?

speaker: Schenkman
text: Thanks to our sessions, Maris has been unafraid to show me the real woman inside.

speaker: Niles
text: Damn you, I trusted you!  Because you were supposed to be helping us!  And I liked you too, you bastard!  You betrayed my confidence and my friendship, and you seduced my wife!

speaker: Schenkman
text: Wow, there's a lot of new issues here, aren't there?  Think maybe we should kick it up to three sessions a week? _Niles sees red and starts to throttle Schenkman.  As Schenkman yells for mercy, we FADE OUT.  Scene Two The scene changes to Niles's private practice.  In the waiting room Frasier greets a rather late Niles._

speaker: Frasier
text: You are twenty minutes late.

speaker: Niles
text: Sorry.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_unsatisfied_] "Sorry?"  This is your group, I've been making small talk with these people for the last twenty minutes. Do you know what small talk is like with people who have a problem communicating?  It's tiny talk!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I just have a lot on my mind right now which I don't care to discuss, so let's just begin and you know what, maybe you should take the lead, OK?

speaker: Frasier
text: Very well. _Niles & Frasier enter the office where several couples are sitting around._

speaker: Niles
text: Evening, all.  Sorry I'm late, my fault.

speaker: Frasier
text: If I know these people, they won't hold a grudge.  I feel that I do know a great deal about this group.  I've spent a good deal of time poring over your case histories.  So, let's begin.  Mrs. Budinger, I see that you're here alone.

speaker: Janice
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is there some reason why Dan couldn't join you?

speaker: Janice
text: No, he's just stubborn sometimes.  He says he doesn't trust psychiatrists.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, well... maybe he's got good reason not to!

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Janice
text: Oh, I think I see what your brother's doing here.  Sometimes we role-play, and I think he's just saying what my husband might say.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sounds promising, why don't we proceed, Janice?  How would you respond to what your husband has just said?

speaker: Janice
text: Well, OK... you know, Dan, I don't think it's psychiatrists that you mistrust, I think that it's me.  Why are you so suspicious lately?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I think you know very well.

speaker: Janice
text: What, a couple of harmless flirtations at parties?  Everyone does that.

speaker: Niles
text: Did you ever stop to consider how those flirtations might make

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to a confused couple_] He's empathizing with the husband, we call this "empathizing."

speaker: Janice
text: Well, what about you?  Are you going to tell me you've never even looked at anyone else?

speaker: Niles
text: [_standing up_] Don't you _dare_ bring her into this!  She is clean and pure and decent!

speaker: Frasier
text: Sometimes empathizing involves a bit of dramatic license.

speaker: Niles
text: At least I've always been faithful to you!

speaker: Janice
text: [_stands up_] I've always been faithful to you!

speaker: Niles
text: I wanted to believe that more than anything in the world, but now, now... [_cries_] I don't see how I possibly can!

speaker: Frasier
text: Did I mention that my brother's one of the greatest empathizers in the business?

speaker: Niles
text: Now I just want to DIE!

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, perhaps now would be a good time to take our fifteen minute break, why don't we? [_the patients start to leave the room_] We've had quite a catharsis here - now traditionally it is the patients that make the breakthroughs, but we mustn't be sticklers.

speaker: Janice
text: Dan and I have never cheated on another!  You've got to believe me!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I do, I do, Janice, and please remember, no-one is here to judge anyone else's behavior. [_closes door and shouts at Niles_] What the hell are you doing, you lunatic?!

speaker: Niles
text: Maris is having an affair with Schenkman!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_stunned_] Schenkman!  Why, that contemptible bastard.

speaker: Niles
text: He was waiting at the house for her when I got there.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm so sorry, Niles.  Is there anything I can do?

speaker: Niles
text: I don't see how.  They're in love, they plan to get married!

speaker: Frasier
text: He told you that?

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm-hmm.  And she confirmed it when she walked in - once she'd stopped shrieking and we'd coaxed her down off the canopy.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm just shocked.  Things seemed to be going so well with the two of you.

speaker: Niles
text: That's what I thought. [_thinks_] You know, maybe Maris's feelings for Dr. Schenkman aren't real!  Maybe this is simply a case of transference.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, patients often do believe they've fallen in love with their analysts, it's very common, it's happened to everyone.

speaker: Niles
text: I know, it's happened to me!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, get out of town!

speaker: Niles
text: Several times.  Well, I bet that's exactly what's going on here!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to himself_] I've never had a patient fall in love with me.

speaker: Niles
text: Schenkman's an authority figure, Maris is easily influenced...

speaker: Frasier
text: Not even that fat lady who brought me fudge.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd be a fool to let her go if it's as simple as that!

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, Niles, you're not thinking clearly.  You're just grasping at straws.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, you're wrong.  I owe it to my marriage to give this just one more shot.

speaker: Frasier
text: How?!  What more could you possibly do?

speaker: Niles
text: I just need to talk to her alone.  Try to make her realize what a mistake she's making.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, just bear one thing in mind... _Frasier follows Niles out of his office and shouts in earshot of the listening patients._

speaker: Frasier
text: Sometimes a marriage is just bad, doomed, and no amount of discussion will save it! _Niles leaves; Frasier turns back to the patients, who are all staring at him, aghast._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, then... shall we resume? **THE GOING RATE FOR CLOSURE IS $1411.80** _Scene Three Later, Frasier is on the phone to Daphne in his apartment._

speaker: Frasier
text: No, don't worry, Daphne, that's all right, you have fun.  I'll be fine.  See you tomorrow, everything will be fine, OK.  Oh, Dad?  No, he's not even back from his big date yet! [_laughs_] Maybe I'll see him in the morning too. [_she prolongs him_] Alright... yes, it is a very romantic story.  OK, Daphne... Yes, yes, they do make a very cute couple.  Anyway... Right, right, Daphne, yes I suppose they do owe it all to you, don't they?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, there's the door.  OK. [_puts phone down_] _It seems that Frasier simply saved a very tired Niles from ringing it, who wearily enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles?  I thought you were talking with Maris.

speaker: Niles
text: It's over.  Let her marry Schenkman, they deserve each other.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm sorry, Niles.  What happened?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I reached the front gate and I was just about to ring the doorbell to ask her to let me in, when it suddenly dawned on me how many hours I have spent pleading with that woman through gates, through windows, through key holes, and through transoms and... in one disastrous instance, through the pet door.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I remember dabbing Bactine on those Chihuahua bites.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I decided no more.  I actually looked up at the house and said, "Goodbye, Maris.  I hope you have a happy life but I don't have to take anymore of your crap ever again!"  And I turned on my heel and walked away.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's a courageous decision.  How do you feel?

speaker: Niles
text: Not bad, surprisingly.  I'm glad I went over, I needed the closure.  Now that it's over I feel a little sad of course, but also strangely liberated.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm very proud of you. _Frasier hugs his brother.  They spend a few moments in silence before Martin enters fresh from his date._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Dad, you're back.  How did things go with Mrs. Crowley?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh great, fabulous.  Right up until the time she introduced me to my date.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought she was your date.

speaker: Martin
text: So did I.  Turns out my date was her mother.  Eighty-six years young.  I guess there was a little miscommunication when she invited me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gee, I'm almost afraid to ask this; "how was mom?"

speaker: Martin
text: Well, she was very nice.  Sleepy. [_Frasier and Niles laugh_] But she smiled a lot, showed me pictures of her great- grandchildren.  She couldn't remember any of their names, but what the hell, she couldn't remember mine either. [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I think we could all use a little something from the bar.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I could use a big something.

speaker: Frasier
text: It hasn't been a good day all around.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, dad, uh... Maris and I have split up for good.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I'm sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: She-She's in love with someone else.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Niles.  You all right?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I will be.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_hands drinks around_] Well, this may come as small consolation to you, but I believe that you each have a lot of work to do to catch up to me in the failed romance department.  Divorced twice, left at the alter once. _They share a chuckle, raise their glasses in a silent toast, and drink. Martin takes the bottle._

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I haven't exactly been burning things up lately.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_as his glass is refilled_] Thank you, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: [_fills Niles's, then his own_] Things with Sherry fizzled, then Sleeping Beauty tonight...

speaker: Martin
text: I think maybe I deserve the booby prize. _They lift their glasses again, mumbling toasts, and drink.  Niles takes the bottle._

speaker: Niles
text: I'll challenge you!  Fifteen years with Maris, I end up in bed with her lover. _Niles pours Martin's drink, but Martin nearly drops his glass when he hears this._

speaker: Martin
text: Geez, I didn't need to hear that!

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, it was an accident.  It was pitch dark, I thought he was Maris.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a natural mistake.  Uh, what tipped you off?

speaker: Niles
text: The heat from her side of the bed!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I think we have a three-way tie. [_lifts his glass_] Here's to the Crane boys - love's big losers.

speaker: Niles
text: You know, I said I needed closure.  But I won't have until I do one more thing. [_takes off ring and heads to the balcony_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, now be careful, Niles.  You know, from this height that could hurt somebody.

speaker: Niles
text: [_looks out_] All clear! _Niles throws his ring over the balcony and they all rush to see it drop._

speaker: Niles
text: Goodbye, Maris!  You've hurt me for the last time!

speaker: Martin
text: Uh Niles, is that your Mercedes parked down there?

speaker: Martin
text: Whoa! [_then_] Oh well, a good body shop will be able to pound that out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's Saturday night.  And here we are... again.

speaker: Martin
text: Wonder how many women are out there tonight without a date.

speaker: Niles
text: Thousands!  Thousands of opportunities for us to humiliate ourselves.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shouting_] Well, come and get us, Seattle!  Three Cranes, no waiting!

speaker: Martin
text: We're desperate!

speaker: Frasier
text: We're ludicrous!

speaker: Niles
text: We're pathetic!  _They all chuckle to themselves before quieting down and staring, pensively, from the balcony. The emotional scene FADES OUT.  END OF ACT TWO. (Time: 20:38)_
